text:
I am trying to solve a diophantine equation using a simple for loop to solve this equation:
`f(x,y) = x^2 + y^3 == 31`
So i have defined:
`X = collect(1:1:10)` e `Y= collect(1:1:10)`
and tried:
```for i in Y
    for j in X
          println(i, j, f(i,j))
    end
end```
There's a True return(2,3) and I want to get the X and Y of this True return and not all the false results…but I am not able to do it so far…any tips?
How can i code this?

elements.text: I am trying to solve a diophantine equation using a simple for loop to solve this equation:

for i in Y
    for j in X
          println(i, j, f(i,j))
    end
end

There's a True return(2,3) and I want to get the X and Y of this True return and not all the false results…but I am not able to do it so far…any tips?
How can i code this?

text:
```for i in Y, j in X
  f(i,j) != 31 && continue
  println("i = $i, j = $j, f(i,j) = $(f(i,j))")
end```

elements.text:
for i in Y, j in X
  f(i,j) != 31 && continue
  println("i = $i, j = $j, f(i,j) = $(f(i,j))")
end

text: i dont know why but its not returning anything

elements.text: i dont know why but its not returning anything

text:
```for i in Y, j in X
  !f(i,j) && continue
  println("i = $i, j = $j, f(i,j) = $(f(i,j))")
end```

elements.text:
for i in Y, j in X
  !f(i,j) && continue
  println("i = $i, j = $j, f(i,j) = $(f(i,j))")
end

text: It didn't work because Syx thought the function is returning the value of `x^2 + y^3`  but it is returning the boolean value of whether `x^2 + y^3` equal to 31. So just replace `f(i,j) != 31` with `!f(i,j)`

elements.text: It didn't work because Syx thought the function is returning the value of
but it is returning the boolean value of whether

text: If we believe Wikipedia, mathematicians are still searching for a solution for 114 <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sums_of_three_cubes>

elements.text: If we believe Wikipedia, mathematicians are still searching for a solution for 114

text: And the solution will likely involve numbers with, say 60 bits, rather than 10 bits, in which case your loops will have to run a bit longer :wink:

text:
If you're not too comfortable with the `&& continue`  syntax then there's also this code too. I find the one below easier to understand. Basically it says that if f(i, j) returns true, then print it out. But learning what `&&` and `continue`  does in the future will be helpful too.

```for i in Y, j in X
   if f(i,j)
       println("i = $i, j = $j, f(i,j) = $(f(i,j))")
   end
end```

elements.text: If you're not too comfortable with the
syntax then there's also this code too. I find the one below easier to understand. Basically it says that if f(i, j) returns true, then print it out. But learning what
does in the future will be helpful too.

for i in Y, j in X
   if f(i,j)
       println("i = $i, j = $j, f(i,j) = $(f(i,j))")
   end
end

text:
Also for future reference, I don't think you need to `collect` your ranges. Collecting the range means the computer has to take all the numbers in the range and store it in memory as an array. But if you just use the ranges directly, I don't think the computer needs to do that. It does something a bit smarter. You can just do

`X = 1:1:10` 
`Y = 1:1:10`
